p.s: Emended description of the genus Oerskovia

Emendation is based on the original generic description of Prauser et al. (1970), supplemented with results on peptidoglycan structure, cellular fatty acid and physiological data (Stackebrandt et al., 1982) and the results of Biolog (Table 4) and API Coryne (Table 5) tests. The emended description of Oerskovia by Lechevalier (1972) is not taken into account, as Oerskovia xanthineolytica, the description of which was the reason for the emendation, has been reclassified as a strain of Cellulomonas cellulans (Stackebrandt et al., 1980), now classified as Cellulosimicrobium cellulans (Schumann et al., 2001). Has extensively branching vegetative hyphae (approx. 0.5 μm in diameter), growing on the surface of and penetrating into the agar, which break up into motile rod-like elements. Growth appears bacteroid in smears. No aerial mycelium. Motile or non-motile. Gram-positive, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive. Aerobic to facultatively anaerobic; strictly aerobic strains may occur. Major fatty acids are ai-C15:0 and C16:0; i-C15:0, C14:0 and ai-C17:0 occur in smaller amounts. Major isoprenoid quinone is MK-9(H4). Diamino acid of peptidoglycan peptide side chain is L-lysine ; the interpeptide bridge consists of either L-Thr←D-Asp or L-Thr←D-Glu. Muramic acid residues are acetylated. Major polar lipids are phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol. The G+­C content of the DNA of the type species is 70.5-75.0 mol%. Widely distributed in soil. The type species is Oerskovia turbata.
